segments.text: And now from the University of Chicago Institute of Politics and CNN, the AX files with your
host David Axelrod.
You want to get an argument going in American politics today.
Good place to start is on the issue of trade.
It's an issue that's divided both parties.
It's an issue that was central to the last presidential campaign.
And someone who was deeply invested in that discussion was Michael Froman, who was the
United States Trade Representative under the Obama Administration, and a central player
in the negotiation of the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
Michael came by the Institute of Politics the other day to talk about where the issue
of trade goes from here.
And while he was here, we sat down to talk about that, but also his life and career.
Michael Froman, an old friend of mine, welcome to the AX files and to the Institute of Politics.
Great to be here.
Interesting time to take up the issue of trade, and we'll get to that.
But I never really had a chance when we worked together because we were in the midst
of a financial crisis and a few other things to talk to you about how you got to where
we were in your own life.
So tell me about growing up in the Bay Area back in the day when you were a kid, and how
that helped formulate what you would become.
Sure.
Well, you know, I grew up in the Bay Area and took a year, I was going to be a doctor,
and I took a year off after high school and traveled around.
What tell me about your family though?
I guess your dad was in the furniture business?
My dad was in a furniture business, had a small store in the local town.
I worked there during the summers, moving furniture, dusting furniture.
It was my summer job.
He was an immigrant.
He was born in Berlin.
He left Berlin in 1936 as a refugee to what was in Palestine.
I grew up there until 1950 and came to the US to go to college.
I went to Berkeley.
I met my mom there.
We settled down in, they settled down in Marine County, just north of San Francisco.
So he was first generation immigrants.
And I think that had a big impact on my life.
He was very much involved, followed history and Middle East politics and the like, and
had a big impact on me throughout my life.
And you were active in Jewish issues in the community when you were a kid?
That's right.
In fact, that year I took off after high school was to work for a Jewish youth organization,
allowed me to travel all around the country a bit internationally.
That's what really changed my focus from doing something in science to doing something in
politics.
And so I decided to come east, went to school at Princeton, studied international relations,
and kept on going to that.
So you were a good student, obviously.
I guess I did, okay.
Yes, yeah.
And from Princeton, you pursued a doctorate.
I pursued a doctorate in international relations at Oxford, and then I went to law school.
It's a Harvard law school.
And that's right.
Why?
I mean, why did you decide to just love schools?
Well, you know, I had planned to be a lawyer or to go to law school anyway.
I wasn't sure I'd ever practiced, but thought I would go to law school.
Why?
You know, I think it was, I was convinced, and I think in retrospect, I was right, that
learning a coherent way of thinking.
There are lots of different models or frameworks one can develop in one's life, but the way
of a lawyer of working through a problem in a concerted manner, looking at both sides
of the issue, having to make arguments on one side of the issue and understand the
strengths and weaknesses of those arguments, I found to be a very attractive way of organizing
my thoughts and something that I used every day, even though I never practiced law.
And while you were at Harvard, you had some illustrious classmates, not the least of which
was Barack Obama.
Indeed.
I mean, I came to know you as a friend of Barack Obama's when he was earlier in his political
career, but you worked with him then.
We were classmates.
We worked on Law Review together.
He, of course, went on to be president of Law Review.
I was just a mere editor there.
But if you've ever been in law school or know anything about Law Review, you spend an
inordinate amount of time, late into the nights, sitting around the table doing work on articles
together.
And so it gave us an opportunity to get to that.
And what was your observation of him back then?
Well, he stood out in everybody's mind immediately.
Now, I won't say that I thought then he'd be president of the United States.
Maybe some people did have that kind of foresight.
I think we all thought he would go into politics.
But whether it was-
Why'd you feel that way?
Well, it was a time.
This was in the late 80s, early 90s.
It was a time on law school campuses when there was a lot of division.
There had been the critical legal studies movement.
It was followed by the rise of the Federalist Society.
So there was a lot of sort of right-left divide on law schools.
There were divided students, there were divided faculties.
And he was a figure who came into Law Review determined to try and bridge the differences.
And a lot of the attributes that later became obvious as a senator, as a candidate for president,
as president, you could see even back then in terms of his commitment to try and bridge
differences, his ability to reach out to people and try and build consensus.
And obviously it was on a much smaller scale over much less consequences.
Yeah, although with a bunch of probably rigorous thinkers.
Oh, that's right.
That's right.
And people who felt very strongly about their perspectives.
It's interesting because he had come from being a community organizer where he was also
trying to bridge differences, but with an entirely different group of folks.
That's right.
Did the fact that he became president of the Law Review, it was national news.
Was it regarded as such on campus?
Was it a big thing?
It was a big deal.
It was the first African-American to be elected in, I think what was then, 104 years of the
history of the Law Review.
So it was a big deal on campus.
He was a big deal, and not just because of the Law Review.
I had a few classes with him.
He stood out in those classes when he opened his mouth and expressed his view for so all
he did it judiciously.
But when he did, it had an impact and he had a perspective, a more mature perspective,
many respects.
And he was older than...
He was older.
He had taken a few years off.
You both were older because you had taken time off for different things.
That's right.
He had gone to organize and I had done my doctor in the meantime.
And did you have a...
What was your personal relationship with him like then?
Yeah, it was good.
I was not a close buddy.
I was not a roommate as some of the press had sort of reported on.
But we were colleagues on Law Review.
We spent a lot of time together.
Every night at 10 o'clock, everyone put their work away and broke to have a snack or to
watch the news and talk about what was going on.
We had the first Gulf War that was launched while we were students there together.
It was a big debate among the editors there about what was going on in the Middle East.
And I just remember a very vibrant, thoughtful discussion that he brought to the table about
what was ever going on on TV, was every way on on the campus.
He went back to Illinois to teach and to practice civil rights law and ultimately to
run for office.
You went right to Washington.
Was that your intent to get right into the thick of government?
Well, I first went to Europe and went to Brussels, worked for the European Commission.
And then my wife and I went to Albania.
Oh, that's right.
Legal reform.
And then ended up in Washington about a year later.
And that was the intent.
I was very focused on doing government service and being in the government.
And you were a protégé of Bob Rubens, who was built ultimately, Bill Clinton's Treasury
Secretary, head of the NEC, before that.
He was a, he loomed large over the economic policy of the 90s.
And some on the left were unhappy with the approach he took.
What was, you guys came to office at a time when there was a recession and had some big
fights over tax policy and so on.
What distinguished the Reuben years there with President Clinton?
Well, look, I think one of the things he established first as head of the National Economic Council,
but then also when he was Treasury Secretary, was the importance of having a full debate
around the table.
And he viewed his role as head of the NEC, not just to express his point of view, but
to make sure that alternative opposing points of view were also represented there and that
the President had the benefit of differing perspectives there.
So oftentimes we'd be sitting in meetings and he would be making the actual, the opposite
argument of what he, I knew he believed in, just to make sure that it was on the table.
And I thought, I learned a lot from that in terms of the importance of a fair and open
system.
And President Clinton and President Obama both valued having that kind of debate where
they could see all the perspectives being presented them so that they could make the
ultimate decision.
Well, a good way to win an argument is to argue both sides of it, I guess.
Yeah.
There you go.
But you know what the, you know, there was a great emphasis on balancing the budget and
you know, great, a great emphasis on trade, which we will talk about.
It was a big dividing line within welfare reform.
There was a big dividing line within the left and the Democratic Party over those policies
and some of, there are still reverberations of some of those debates today.
I think that's right.
I mean, the Clinton administration came in in the context of a recession, put together
policies and you're right, it reflected fiscal conservatism, it reflected pro trade perspectives.
Although one of them was also a high-end tax cut that was quite, quite a row.
And it led to a very strong recovery in the 1990s, including the creation of 20 million
new jobs.
So there was a robust debate within the government about this.
There were also quite good results for the outcome.
Let me, we'll, we'll, we'll, we'll, there's a lot more to talk about on trade, but on,
that was really a period in which trade was not only hotly debated, but was the establishment
of a global trading structure was really front and center.
And the reverberations of that today, and we saw it in the election of Donald Trump,
was that a whole lot of people in places like, you know, Galesboro, Illinois, and, and,
and, you know, Detroit and all kinds of industrial towns large and small saw the offshoring
of jobs.
And so people identify the decline of the middle class in those communities with trade.
Is that a, is it a fair critique?
Well, like I think most economists will tell you that 80% or more of the effect on jobs
is from technology, not from trade.
Even then?
Well, even then.
I mean, you've seen the decline in the percentage of manufacturing workers, for example, in the
United States for, for 60 years, long before there was any trade agreement.
And this is before the WTO existed, before China joined the WTO, before NAFTA was fully
implemented.
Economies, including not just the US, but other major industrial economies, were going
through transition with more and more productivity, more technology introduced into the workplace.
The absolute amount of product produced manufacturing in the United States continued to go up.
In fact, last year, we've had the highest amount of manufacturing product produced in
the United States ever.
You've also had some return of manufacturing over the last few years as wages elsewhere
have begun to catch up.
That's right.
Over the last five years, you had about 800,000 new manufacturing jobs added.
But there has been a secular trend of increased production with fewer workers.
And that is largely because of technology.
But back in that day, there were, you know, you could, you could, in fact, well, this
predated, as you point out, some of these agreements.
I mean, Obama worked in the shadow of closed steel mills, some of which were shipped overseas.
But a lot of these communities saw a lot of factories close down and move to places where
labor was much cheaper.
But I had to make your job harder in selling trade treaties when it became your job to
do so.
Well, absolutely.
Because I think there's a tendency to conflate globalization with trade agreements.
Globalization has certainly had an impact on the US economy, on jobs, on wages.
There's no doubt about that.
But globalization is a force.
It's the effect of the containerization of shipping, which made it easier to have supply
chains around the world.
In the services sector, it's the effect of the spread of broadband, which made it possible
to do things in India overnight, rather than having workers in the United States.
These technological developments very much facilitated the spread of globalization with
or without trade agreements.
You take steel, for example, we had zero tariffs on steel.
We don't have any production on steel in the United States.
That's regardless of any trade agreement.
So as we've seen steel meals close, it is because either there's been cheaper labor
abroad.
It's been easier to ship steel from one country to another.
The costs of doing trade have declined.
Where we have seen a resurgence of steel production in the US, it's because it's been of a more
high tech sort with more automation.
And that has shown how the impact of automation has the impact that automation has had on
the workplace.
Back over the decades that you've been working on this issue and say, there are things we
should have done, both in terms of how we negotiated these agreements and how we dealt
with the impacts of globalization in particularly these industrial communities.
Absolutely.
Look, I think one of the lessons learned of Tic NAFTA as an example, the Clinton administration
inherited NAFTA and added labor and environmental side agreements.
And the idea behind it was if we're going to be integrated with our neighboring countries,
it's important that they not be able to avoid basic labor and environmental protections
in order to get a competitive advantage on us.
But these side agreements were not particularly strong standards and they weren't fully enforceable.
And as you know, when Senator Obama was running for president, he called for the renegotiation
of NAFTA and he was quite clear on what it meant.
And he talked about how labor and environment have to be treated just as seriously as any
other issue in a trade negotiation.
And that's what we did under his leadership when we negotiated the Trans-Pacific Partnership,
which had binding and enforceable, very strong labor obligations in Mexico and Canada as well
as 40% of the global economy.
I mean, one of the paradoxes in talking about this issue though is the argument that you
would hear about in favor of trade agreements.
And part was that by lifting some countries that were poorer countries, developing countries,
that you could create markets for American goods and create more social tranquility.
And from a security and strategic standpoint, there were advantages to that.
So in a sense, there was a concession that you may be shipping some opportunity to these
other countries as part of the deal.
Well, look, we are already an open economy in the United States.
Our average applied tariff, the tax we put on imports.
Until now, at least.
Until now is one and a half percent.
If you take the TPP countries, 80% of what we import from TPP countries already comes
in duty-free.
So we're already very open, but we face much bigger barriers abroad.
Vietnam has got 70% tariffs on autos.
So if you want to sell autos to Vietnam, Vietnam, 90 million people growing 6% a year, a poor
country, but with an emerging middle class.
And they want the kinds of things that the US produces.
They want our autos.
They want our tractors.
They want our agricultural products.
They want our services.
You have faced two choices if they have barriers.
You can either close down your auto plant in the United States and move it to Vietnam
to serve that market, or you can keep the auto plant in the United States, tear down
barriers to Vietnam, and expand production here and export from here to Vietnam.
Our view is that's the right approach to go.
You want more production in the United States, more manufacturing in the United States.
But since 95% of the world's consumers live outside the United States, we need to do
everything we can to remove barriers to those markets and then raise standards in those markets
so that they're not competing with us on an unfair level playing field.
And that's what we tried to do through our trade policy.
We talked a little bit earlier before we began recording about some of the, about the need
for transitional programs to help people in an economy that's changing at like warp
speed, not just because of trade, but because of automation.
But that's never, and that's been talked about for 20 years, but it's never really been effectively
executed.
Why?
Well, I actually thought that might be one of the silver linings of the recent campaign
because for the first time you had not just Democrats, but Republicans saying we need to
do more for people and for communities that are adversely affected by change.
We have a couple government programs and they do what they do, but we need to have a much
more holistic view of this in terms of both preparing people with the skills that they're
going to need to succeed in a rapidly changing economy and helping those who are adversely
affected by change, where that change comes from technology, from immigration or from
trade to make sure that they can transition to a successful path forward as well.
And we don't do a particularly good job of that.
President Obama had several proposals in budget after budget.
Very scary people.
The podcast is back.
I'm Donnie Wahlberg.
And in season two, we're diving into the story of Paul Bernardo and Carla Homulka.
It seemed like they were the perfect couple, the Ken and Barbie dream marriage.
We expect our monsters to look like monsters and they don't always find out how the couple
next door became the killers known as Ken and Barbie.
Listen to very scary people, the Ken and Barbie killers, wherever you get your podcasts.
The issue of transitional help also requires people to make adjustments in their own lives.
And what you hear often is people who've spent a lifetime, you know, 20 years working in
an industry, 25 years, aren't particularly eager to be told you need to retrain for
something entirely different.
And particularly if that's something entirely different, pays a much lower wage than the
thing that they did before.
Well, look, that's right.
And I think we need to be looking at how do you help provide skills at every stage in
a career.
And by the way, it may not always be a federal government program.
It can be programs that states run, the localities run, the companies run, that educational institutions
that you need to follow.
It could be the catalyst for that.
And presumably the federal government would be that catalyst.
They could be, but there's experimentation going on right now in various states where
they are more proactive than we are at the federal level.
And by the way, we can look around the world too.
There are countries out there that do this much better than we do.
Germany.
Germany on the apprenticeships in Scandinavia.
There are programs where unions play a more active role in helping with transition.
Singapore is a unique city-state situation, but they certainly have a very active program
with helping to identify what skills are going to be needed in helping those workers who
are in sun-setting industries make that transition.
Korea has programs.
So there's a lot I think we can learn from both other countries and from the states and
figure out what can be done at the national levels.
You mentioned unions in the role they can play, but one of the issues that's, one of the
things that's, a third of the country was unionized in the 50s.
And today we're looking at under 10% of private sector, of the private sector economy being
unionized.
And you battled the unions over this issue of trade, but it seems like the decline of
unions also has been a contributory factor to the pressures on the middle class.
And you're now offering them as a kind of, as a participant in the retraining and so
on.
How much, what's your view of unions and the role that they should play as someone who's
tussled with them over this issue?
Well, look, we tussled, but we also spent an enormous effort working with them to understand
what it is they wanted us to do in the trade agreement to particularly raise labor standards
and strengthen workers' rights in other countries.
That's a good in and of itself because it's important to underscore the dignity of work
wherever it's taking place.
But it was also a way, very, you know, from a U.S. perspective of leveling the playing
field.
If workers in Mexico can now have truly independent unions that can strike, that can collectively
bargain in a way that they haven't had before, that's good for Mexican workers, but it's
good for American workers.
And it's through trade agreements that we try and make those changes.
So, you know, my, my, I feel like we partnered with the labor unions in many respects.
They certainly did not agree with us at the end of the day.
They didn't support the end result.
They vehemently opposed the TPP to the point where Hillary Clinton, who was a strong supporter
of the TPP, walked away from it.
And my question always to them is, okay, what then would you have us do?
We live in a global world.
The global economy is real.
Globalization is happening.
We compete with low wage labor right now, whether it's from Mexico or China or Vietnam.
If we do nothing but complain, but don't, but not, or not proactive about trying to
raise labor standards in those countries, then we've done nothing to help support our workers
here in the United States.
At least with your TPP, we were able to take major steps forward.
And what Vietnam agreed to in labor reform, what Mexico agreed to, was a very significant
step forward in terms of raising, strengthening workers' rights in those countries.
It would have benefited American workers.
And instead now, it was the absence of TPP, we're going to compete on an on level playing
field with workers in other countries who don't have the same kind of labor rights that we
have here.
Well, you've heard the president, President Trump invoke the specter of tariffs against
companies that would move plants overseas and then try and re-import their products.
What's wrong with that theory?
Yeah, look, I think there, first of all, there's nothing wrong with the goal of driving more
production, more manufacturing to the United States.
Certainly, it was our perspective in the Obama administration and it's a perspective,
clearly, that President Trump is pursuing as well.
The question is how to get it done.
By raising tariffs on other countries, I think you run three risks.
Retaliation, imitation, and taxation.
Retaliation, that if we do something-
Good iteration there, though.
Isn't that good, right?
Retaliation, in that if we take action that is clearly illegal under our international
obligations, we give license to other countries to raise tariffs or to impose a tax on the
impose other barriers on our exports and that hurts our workers.
We have 11.5 million workers who jobs are dependent on exports.
If we give that open license to others to raise barriers to those exports, our workers
are the ones who are going to be hurt.
Similarly, imitation.
If we ignore our international obligations, it makes it much harder for us to prevent
other countries, like China, from also ignoring their international obligations.
We've lost the moral high ground.
We've given license to other countries just to say, well, it's good enough for the US.
It's good enough for us.
And again, since 95% of the world's consumers are outside the US, 80% of the purchasing
powers outside the US, we need access to those markets if we're going to support good jobs
in the United States.
And the third is taxation.
Raising tariffs on imports is a tax on the consumers who consume those imports.
Exercents are particularly regressive tax.
Low-income Americans spend a disproportionate amount of their income on tradable goods,
clothing, footwear, food.
If you raise tariffs, you are imposing a tax on the parts of American society that can
least afford it.
It's kind of a circular problem though, because if you don't make a livable wage, it's hard
to buy products anyway.
Through our successive trade liberalization over the last 70 years and Second World War,
it's estimated we've added $13,000 to the annual income of every American family on average.
Reversing that is a regressive tax.
I want to talk more about this issue when we get to where we are today, and particularly
where we are in the world with this new paradigm of President Trump.
I want to return to your narrative.
You left government, you followed Bob Rubin to Citigroup, and you spent a decade in various
positions, high positions there.
When you saw the rise of a big bull wave on Wall Street, and you also saw a crash, what
happened from you, as someone who was inside, did you sense, did you feel that things were
surging out of control?
Did you have fears about where Wall Street was going?
I think there are lots of different parts of the financial sector, and some parts were
closer to those successes than others.
My last job at Citigroup was investing in infrastructure in the United States and around
the world.
It was quite different from mortgage, bank securities, or things of that sort.
I think one certainly follows it and has a feeling for, well, are the markets pricing
risk adequately or not, but if you're in a different part of the financial sector, it's
a little hard to have a textured understanding or an appreciation of what's going on.
You left shortly after that because you joined the administration that then had to deal with
the crisis.
When Lehman Brothers collapsed, what was the sense within the community of where things
were at that moment?
What were your fears?
What were your concerns?
I think everyone was trying to digest what it meant for an institution like that to collapse
and what the spillover effects would be more broadly on the economy.
It was a new event that people hadn't experienced before at that scale.
It was a lot to digest.
I think a lot of unanticipated impact that people were trying to do.
Citigroup was in the middle of it.
Citigroup was considered a very vulnerable institution.
I remember it because our friend Obama was running for president and was called on to
help support the TARP highly unpopular, which he did in the middle of a campaign and worked
with the Bush administration to do it.
But the level of concern about what the impact of not stepping in at that moment would be
for the country was tremendous.
We did see the global economy enveloped in this.
I guess what I'm asking you is from the inside, what did it look like, what did it feel like
at that moment?
Was there a sense that this thing could come apart?
I think that's right.
There was very much a sense that we were on the verge of what could have been a cataclysmic
event and that it required that kind of intervention, which was, as you said, politically very
unpopular.
It took a lot of courage to move forward with it.
It was still unpopular years later, but it was necessary to prevent the system from collapsing.
It led to, of course, a revision of the financial regulatory framework, which was necessary to
deal with the excesses.
You and I met earlier because there was a group of friends of Obama who would convene
every once in a while to talk about what he was doing, what his plans were.
And you were deeply involved in the transition to the new administration.
And then we met in a different way because I was a senior advisor to the president and
we were going through, this is in the form of confession, by the way, to the world here.
We were going through a situation where the enmity toward Wall Street was ferocious, ferocious,
the anger about what had happened and about the number of people who were losing their
homes, about the crash of the market and all of that was great.
And a lot of it was focused on bonuses that went to people on Wall Street.
You were going to enter the administration and I know we've talked about this.
You remember this call.
I called you and you were due a substantial, I guess would be qualified as a bonus for
your work as you left.
And as you point out, you weren't involved in, but it was all of a piece in the minds
of people.
And I had to tell you that you either had to give up the money or give up public service
or this administration.
I always felt guilty about that.
But how did you receive that?
Well, it came at a very tumultuous time more generally.
Talk a little about that because...
Well, it's a long story, but my son had just died of brain cancer two weeks before.
And that had been our whole...
Jacob, how old was he?
He was about ten and a half.
Yeah.
And how long an ordeal was that?
About two years.
About two years.
So it was a terrible tragedy at home.
There was a lot of tumult there, as you might imagine.
Of course, the tumult going on everywhere in the financial sector, in the economy, me
leaving Citigroup at the same moment and coming into the administration.
A lot of things came together at one moment that was, I don't know if I'd say quite stressful,
to say the least.
But, you know, it also helps put things in perspective.
I remember very well the conversation that you and Raman I had in Ram's office.
My first day, when I reported for work at the Winehouse.
And the president hit me aside earlier that morning to say, this is a problem.
Go talk to David and Ram about this.
And in the grand scope of things, it's only money in that regard.
And there are people who are losing a lot more than that, as you mentioned.
There are homes, there are other livelihoods.
And I just lost something far more valuable than that.
And so, while it was a very difficult period to go through and a difficult issue to work
through, and I appreciate you and Raman, who was the cheapest staff at the time, working
with me through it, at the end of the day, it simply doesn't matter on the same scale
as these other issues.
I raised it in part because we asked people to make a lot of sacrifices, and we tried
to impose certain standards.
And I don't know what standards are being imposed today.
But I'm not sure those questions are being asked.
In part because there are questions about the president that aren't and can't be asked.
The conflicts of interest are not on the top line of concerns today.
But it should be noted that you chose to serve, and it was a sacrifice.
And I had to get that off my chest.
I was the instrument by which I hope you ask you to make that sacrifice.
If I send you state for eight years in which you could have been doing other more
gainful things.
As you know, it is a huge privilege.
It is a huge privilege to serve.
And whatever the sacrifices in terms of opportunity costs or anything else, the only sacrifice
that you really can never recover is the time with your family that you don't spend together.
But beyond that, it's such a huge privilege and honor.
And I think it's one reason why I encourage anybody I know who has any interest under
any president or any administration to go in and serve.
Because there's nothing more valuable, nothing more self-fulfilling than that.
In those early, we talked about the beginning of the crisis, but Obama arrived as it was
cresting.
And it was a global crisis.
You were double-hatted in the National Security Council and on the National Economic Council
to work with the other financial authorities around the world to try and corral this crisis.
And part of it was you were a Sherpa at these global meetings.
What were those meetings like those early meetings when the global economy was cascading out
of control?
Well, there was quite a bit of concern, almost, of the degree of panic among other countries
about what we were going to do to deal with this.
And as you recall, the president was heading to his first summit in April of 2009, so less
than three months as president.
And that summit was really focused on what's going to be the international response to
this crisis.
It was one thing for us to do TARP domestically and the other programs and actions that we
took domestically.
But in order to prevent this from becoming a global depression, we needed the concerted
cooperation of all of the other major economies, including mobilizing resources for the international
monetary fund and for all the other mechanisms of the international system to make sure the
crisis did not spill over into a broader global depression.
I think that one of the things that people don't fully appreciate is the amount of work

It's not as if people show up and say, hey, I got an idea.
All these things are thrashed out beforehand, and then they're refined and discussed in

But your job was to sort of set the agenda to help work with these other countries to

So what kind of tools did you have at that time?
Well, we were all scrambling, and the administration was just being put in place.
Not everybody was being confirmed yet.
But Secretary Geithner at Treasury, Larry Summers at the White House, we all worked

It would show that the major economies had come together this remarkable time to take
the necessary action.
And even though the president had just been inaugurated, it had only been an office, a
matter of weeks, everyone was looking to the US for leadership.
And it underscored for me the lesson that US leadership and engagement is absolutely
critical to getting anything done, positively in the international system.
We're going to take a short break.
We'll be back with Michael Froman.

From CNN, this is tug of war.
Listen, wherever you get your podcasts.
I want to follow up on that point because that's a concern right now.
There is a different philosophy, which is that, and we heard the President Trump articulate

You spent a lot of time on this issue of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the TPP, the

Well, look, I think this is one of the things the great irony is that it's hard to be tough

It's created the Asian Infrastructure Bank.
It's got its own trade agreement called ARSEP with 16 countries ranging from India to

So I think it's going to have quite a long-term negative impact.
How the new administration deals with that and how they engage with the region.
I think that's what remains to be seen and whether they do it through a series of bilateral

Which is what they say they will do.
Right.
Standards are in those deals, do they have strong, labored environmental protections

Do they create an open and free internet like TPP?
Does it protect the digital economy?
That's been so important to our innovation.
That's what remains to be seen.
And what do you think the economic impacts of this will be?
Well, there's both the opportunity lost and then the actual decline.

That two-thirds of the benefits would have gone to workers.

Now multiply that by...
Well, thank God the President is getting tough on the Australians as well.
There you go.
About time someone did that.

Unless we strike a series of agreements that you cobbled together and represent the same

I've heard that.
I've heard that.
I'm not sure there's a full understanding exactly how TPP worked.
Half the countries in TPP, we already had free trade agreements with.

If you bilateralize everything, what's in the interest of these countries who already

What another argument against the TPP was the surrender of sort of sovereignty that

Was that not a legitimate concern?
I think it's a bit of a red herring.
If anything, most of you have looked at TPP, including from these other countries, have

One of the issues that's been criticized in trade agreements quite loudly is the investor

This is the neutral international arbitration.
It's the center warrants concern among others, among others.
This is a provision that is in 3,200 agreements around the world, including 50 that the US

This is nothing new.
In fact, through TPP, what we've done is we've tightened up the standards, made it absolutely

they were disappointed in their profits, that they can't sue because the government

We've raised the standards.
We've closed loopholes.
We've made it much more transparent.
In the absence of TPP, it's the old rules that apply.
Those old rules don't go away.
The 3,200 agreements that are out there among countries, with people can use investor state
disputes, those are still in existence today.
It's just that they have a lower standard.
They're worse from the perspective of the critics of ISDS than what we did in TPP.
You mentioned what we were chatting earlier.
The other difficulty with bilateral agreements is you have to pass them serially.
You have not one debate in Congress, but many debates.
It's a laborious process.
It is, and it's politically costly.
I don't know how difficult trade agreements and trade legislation is to pass.
I don't know many members of Congress who would relish the idea of having 11 votes rather
than one vote in order to have free trade with all these countries.
I think from a political perspective, it's a much more difficult to do.
You don't really see a series of bilateral agreements coming across and being ratified
by Congress in the next four years.
We'll see.
We'll see.
The federal administration has talked about renegotiating NAFTA, doing a bilateral with

Would you have done it as well?
Yeah, I think the President Obama made clear that TTIP, which was our agreement with the

But certainly the UK is a special relationship with them, a quarter of all of our exports

When the UK is out of the EU, I imagine whatever administration is in office would

You said earlier that countries, even if they had differences with the US, looked to the

What does the potential dissolution of the European Union?
If that's what happens in countries start withdrawing from it, the absence of an agreement,
a European agreement with the US, the one that you were working on, what does that mean strategically
in that region?
Well, I think it does have important strategic implications.
First, I think any trade agreement needs to be justified on the economics.
It's got to be good for jobs, wages here in the United States.
These also have big strategic implications.
At a time when Russia has been active on the periphery of Europe, when you've got the
involvement in eastern Ukraine, you have meddling in the affairs of western Europe,
having a transatlantic relationship, a strong transatlantic relationship, I think has strategic
importance as well.
There were issues that we were discussing in TTIP that would have enhanced the energy
security of Europe, so they'd be less dependent, potentially, on Russia for their energy resources.
Those are all part and parcel of what trade agreements can contribute beyond the pure
economics, having a political and strategic importance as well.
Let me ask you to step outside your specific portfolio.
There are a couple of elections this year in Europe, one in France and one in Germany,
in Germany, Angela Merkel, who has been very central to a lot of your work and very central

Powerful figure is the German Chancellor.
She's up for real action.
In France, you have a presidential election in which the National Front candidate, Marine
Le Pen, now appears to be destined to be one of the two finalists.
What are the implications of that strategically for the United States?
Well, I think these are critical.
When you look at Europe and you see slow and uneven growth, you see the rise of right-wing
populism, as you've mentioned France and Germany, but you also have the Netherlands and several
other countries where you've seen the rise of right-wing populism.
You've seen the distrust of institutions and the tensions with the whole European integration
project.
It's paralyzed Europe.
It really has made it very difficult for Europe to play a more significant role both in
terms of addressing its own problems, but also of role in the world.
That's bad for us.
We want a strong Europe.
We want to have a strong partner across the Atlantic who we may not always agree on everything,
who's values we broadly share and who we can work with to make sure that positive things
are going on elsewhere, not only economically, but whether it's around climate change or
whether it's around political issues, strategic issues, security issues.
This is not good for the United States to see weakness, paralysis, and dissolution in
Europe.
On the other hand, I think Russia is enjoying seeing these dynamics at work and is taking
advantage of them.
We have a lot at stake in how these issues get worked out over the next year or two.
We should acknowledge that right-wing populism and nationalism isn't simply a movement,
a stride Europe.
That was a lot of what propelled Donald Trump to the presidency.
What is your level of concern about the future of liberal democracies?
Well, it's significant, the level of concern.
I think it goes to what we're seeing both in Europe and in the United States.
I think we're seeing certain institutions tested, certain legal regimes tested, to see just
how strong they are.
Certain things I think we've taken for granted we're learning have been more a matter of

That's going to require us to rethink things as we come out of this.
There are real issues, the anger that we saw here in the United States in this election

It's much easier to blame a foreigner for problems, whether it's immigrants or whether
it's a foreign trade partner.
Well, the overlay of the migration issue in Europe, immigration issue here, terrorism,
there are a lot of stresses on the system.
That's right.
As you mentioned, Chancellor Merkel, I think has been very much up front in trying to defend
and preserve the so-called liberal democratic order in the context of these systems.
Yeah, I think our election is going to be a real harbinger in the next year.
Obviously, France can be important as well.
What's next for you?
It takes some time and process the experience that of the last eight years and then think
through what to do next.
It's been a lot of time with my family.
You can catch up with my kids and think about how I want to contribute next.
Well, and you see yourself in some form of, in the public sphere.
I'm at the Institute of Politics, so we're about the business of encouraging that.
I think you've given a lot of your life to this, but I think it's hard to step away
from these issues of public importance.
So in some form or another, I imagine I'll stay involved.
Like, from and thank you for your friendship, thank you for being at the Institute of Politics

Thanks very much.

text: And now from the University of Chicago Institute of Politics and CNN, the AX files with your host David Axelrod. You want to get an argument going in American politics today. Good place to start is on the issue of trade. It's an issue that's divided both parties. It's an issue that was central to the last presidential campaign. And someone who was deeply invested in that discussion was Michael Froman, who was the United States Trade Representative under the Obama Administration, and a central player in the negotiation of the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Michael came by the Institute of Politics the other day to talk about where the issue of trade goes from here. And while he was here, we sat down to talk about that, but also his life and career. Michael Froman, an old friend of mine, welcome to the AX files and to the Institute of Politics. Great to be here. Interesting time to take up the issue of trade, and we'll get to that. But I never really had a chance when we worked together because we were in the midst of a financial crisis and a few other things to talk to you about how you got to where we were in your own life. So tell me about growing up in the Bay Area back in the day when you were a kid, and how that helped formulate what you would become. Sure. Well, you know, I grew up in the Bay Area and took a year, I was going to be a doctor, and I took a year off after high school and traveled around. What tell me about your family though? I guess your dad was in the furniture business? My dad was in a furniture business, had a small store in the local town. I worked there during the summers, moving furniture, dusting furniture. It was my summer job. He was an immigrant. He was born in Berlin. He left Berlin in 1936 as a refugee to what was in Palestine. I grew up there until 1950 and came to the US to go to college. I went to Berkeley. I met my mom there. We settled down in, they settled down in Marine County, just north of San Francisco. So he was first generation immigrants. And I think that had a big impact on my life. He was very much involved, followed history and Middle East politics and the like, and had a big impact on me throughout my life. And you were active in Jewish issues in the community when you were a kid? That's right. In fact, that year I took off after high school was to work for a Jewish youth organization, allowed me to travel all around the country a bit internationally. That's what really changed my focus from doing something in science to doing something in politics. And so I decided to come east, went to school at Princeton, studied international relations, and kept on going to that. So you were a good student, obviously. I guess I did, okay. Yes, yeah. And from Princeton, you pursued a doctorate. I pursued a doctorate in international relations at Oxford, and then I went to law school. It's a Harvard law school. And that's right. Why? I mean, why did you decide to just love schools? Well, you know, I had planned to be a lawyer or to go to law school anyway. I wasn't sure I'd ever practiced, but thought I would go to law school. Why? You know, I think it was, I was convinced, and I think in retrospect, I was right, that learning a coherent way of thinking. There are lots of different models or frameworks one can develop in one's life, but the way of a lawyer of working through a problem in a concerted manner, looking at both sides of the issue, having to make arguments on one side of the issue and understand the strengths and weaknesses of those arguments, I found to be a very attractive way of organizing my thoughts and something that I used every day, even though I never practiced law. And while you were at Harvard, you had some illustrious classmates, not the least of which was Barack Obama. Indeed. I mean, I came to know you as a friend of Barack Obama's when he was earlier in his political career, but you worked with him then. We were classmates. We worked on Law Review together. He, of course, went on to be president of Law Review. I was just a mere editor there. But if you've ever been in law school or know anything about Law Review, you spend an inordinate amount of time, late into the nights, sitting around the table doing work on articles together. And so it gave us an opportunity to get to that. And what was your observation of him back then? Well, he stood out in everybody's mind immediately. Now, I won't say that I thought then he'd be president of the United States. Maybe some people did have that kind of foresight. I think we all thought he would go into politics. But whether it was- Why'd you feel that way? Well, it was a time. This was in the late 80s, early 90s. It was a time on law school campuses when there was a lot of division. There had been the critical legal studies movement. It was followed by the rise of the Federalist Society. So there was a lot of sort of right-left divide on law schools. There were divided students, there were divided faculties. And he was a figure who came into Law Review determined to try and bridge the differences. And a lot of the attributes that later became obvious as a senator, as a candidate for president, as president, you could see even back then in terms of his commitment to try and bridge differences, his ability to reach out to people and try and build consensus. And obviously it was on a much smaller scale over much less consequences. Yeah, although with a bunch of probably rigorous thinkers. Oh, that's right. That's right. And people who felt very strongly about their perspectives. It's interesting because he had come from being a community organizer where he was also trying to bridge differences, but with an entirely different group of folks. That's right. Did the fact that he became president of the Law Review, it was national news. Was it regarded as such on campus? Was it a big thing? It was a big deal. It was the first African-American to be elected in, I think what was then, 104 years of the history of the Law Review. So it was a big deal on campus. He was a big deal, and not just because of the Law Review. I had a few classes with him. He stood out in those classes when he opened his mouth and expressed his view for so all he did it judiciously. But when he did, it had an impact and he had a perspective, a more mature perspective, many respects. And he was older than... He was older. He had taken a few years off. You both were older because you had taken time off for different things. That's right. He had gone to organize and I had done my doctor in the meantime. And did you have a... What was your personal relationship with him like then? Yeah, it was good. I was not a close buddy. I was not a roommate as some of the press had sort of reported on. But we were colleagues on Law Review. We spent a lot of time together. Every night at 10 o'clock, everyone put their work away and broke to have a snack or to watch the news and talk about what was going on. We had the first Gulf War that was launched while we were students there together. It was a big debate among the editors there about what was going on in the Middle East. And I just remember a very vibrant, thoughtful discussion that he brought to the table about what was ever going on on TV, was every way on on the campus. He went back to Illinois to teach and to practice civil rights law and ultimately to run for office. You went right to Washington. Was that your intent to get right into the thick of government? Well, I first went to Europe and went to Brussels, worked for the European Commission. And then my wife and I went to Albania. Oh, that's right. Legal reform. And then ended up in Washington about a year later. And that was the intent. I was very focused on doing government service and being in the government. And you were a protégé of Bob Rubens, who was built ultimately, Bill Clinton's Treasury Secretary, head of the NEC, before that. He was a, he loomed large over the economic policy of the 90s. And some on the left were unhappy with the approach he took. What was, you guys came to office at a time when there was a recession and had some big fights over tax policy and so on. What distinguished the Reuben years there with President Clinton? Well, look, I think one of the things he established first as head of the National Economic Council, but then also when he was Treasury Secretary, was the importance of having a full debate around the table. And he viewed his role as head of the NEC, not just to express his point of view, but to make sure that alternative opposing points of view were also represented there and that the President had the benefit of differing perspectives there. So oftentimes we'd be sitting in meetings and he would be making the actual, the opposite argument of what he, I knew he believed in, just to make sure that it was on the table. And I thought, I learned a lot from that in terms of the importance of a fair and open system. And President Clinton and President Obama both valued having that kind of debate where they could see all the perspectives being presented them so that they could make the ultimate decision. Well, a good way to win an argument is to argue both sides of it, I guess. Yeah. There you go. But you know what the, you know, there was a great emphasis on balancing the budget and you know, great, a great emphasis on trade, which we will talk about. It was a big dividing line within welfare reform. There was a big dividing line within the left and the Democratic Party over those policies and some of, there are still reverberations of some of those debates today. I think that's right. I mean, the Clinton administration came in in the context of a recession, put together policies and you're right, it reflected fiscal conservatism, it reflected pro trade perspectives. Although one of them was also a high-end tax cut that was quite, quite a row. And it led to a very strong recovery in the 1990s, including the creation of 20 million new jobs. So there was a robust debate within the government about this. There were also quite good results for the outcome. Let me, we'll, we'll, we'll, we'll, there's a lot more to talk about on trade, but on, that was really a period in which trade was not only hotly debated, but was the establishment of a global trading structure was really front and center. And the reverberations of that today, and we saw it in the election of Donald Trump, was that a whole lot of people in places like, you know, Galesboro, Illinois, and, and, and, you know, Detroit and all kinds of industrial towns large and small saw the offshoring of jobs. And so people identify the decline of the middle class in those communities with trade. Is that a, is it a fair critique? Well, like I think most economists will tell you that 80% or more of the effect on jobs is from technology, not from trade. Even then? Well, even then. I mean, you've seen the decline in the percentage of manufacturing workers, for example, in the United States for, for 60 years, long before there was any trade agreement. And this is before the WTO existed, before China joined the WTO, before NAFTA was fully implemented. Economies, including not just the US, but other major industrial economies, were going through transition with more and more productivity, more technology introduced into the workplace. The absolute amount of product produced manufacturing in the United States continued to go up. In fact, last year, we've had the highest amount of manufacturing product produced in the United States ever. You've also had some return of manufacturing over the last few years as wages elsewhere have begun to catch up. That's right. Over the last five years, you had about 800,000 new manufacturing jobs added. But there has been a secular trend of increased production with fewer workers. And that is largely because of technology. But back in that day, there were, you know, you could, you could, in fact, well, this predated, as you point out, some of these agreements. I mean, Obama worked in the shadow of closed steel mills, some of which were shipped overseas. But a lot of these communities saw a lot of factories close down and move to places where labor was much cheaper. But I had to make your job harder in selling trade treaties when it became your job to do so. Well, absolutely. Because I think there's a tendency to conflate globalization with trade agreements. Globalization has certainly had an impact on the US economy, on jobs, on wages. There's no doubt about that. But globalization is a force. It's the effect of the containerization of shipping, which made it easier to have supply chains around the world. In the services sector, it's the effect of the spread of broadband, which made it possible to do things in India overnight, rather than having workers in the United States. These technological developments very much facilitated the spread of globalization with or without trade agreements. You take steel, for example, we had zero tariffs on steel. We don't have any production on steel in the United States. That's regardless of any trade agreement. So as we've seen steel meals close, it is because either there's been cheaper labor abroad. It's been easier to ship steel from one country to another. The costs of doing trade have declined. Where we have seen a resurgence of steel production in the US, it's because it's been of a more high tech sort with more automation. And that has shown how the impact of automation has the impact that automation has had on the workplace. Back over the decades that you've been working on this issue and say, there are things we should have done, both in terms of how we negotiated these agreements and how we dealt with the impacts of globalization in particularly these industrial communities. Absolutely. Look, I think one of the lessons learned of Tic NAFTA as an example, the Clinton administration inherited NAFTA and added labor and environmental side agreements. And the idea behind it was if we're going to be integrated with our neighboring countries, it's important that they not be able to avoid basic labor and environmental protections in order to get a competitive advantage on us. But these side agreements were not particularly strong standards and they weren't fully enforceable. And as you know, when Senator Obama was running for president, he called for the renegotiation of NAFTA and he was quite clear on what it meant. And he talked about how labor and environment have to be treated just as seriously as any other issue in a trade negotiation. And that's what we did under his leadership when we negotiated the Trans-Pacific Partnership, which had binding and enforceable, very strong labor obligations in Mexico and Canada as well as 40% of the global economy. I mean, one of the paradoxes in talking about this issue though is the argument that you would hear about in favor of trade agreements. And part was that by lifting some countries that were poorer countries, developing countries, that you could create markets for American goods and create more social tranquility. And from a security and strategic standpoint, there were advantages to that. So in a sense, there was a concession that you may be shipping some opportunity to these other countries as part of the deal. Well, look, we are already an open economy in the United States. Our average applied tariff, the tax we put on imports. Until now, at least. Until now is one and a half percent. If you take the TPP countries, 80% of what we import from TPP countries already comes in duty-free. So we're already very open, but we face much bigger barriers abroad. Vietnam has got 70% tariffs on autos. So if you want to sell autos to Vietnam, Vietnam, 90 million people growing 6% a year, a poor country, but with an emerging middle class. And they want the kinds of things that the US produces. They want our autos. They want our tractors. They want our agricultural products. They want our services. You have faced two choices if they have barriers.
